standard_metadata.standard_description: Find the area of a rectangle with fractional side lengths by tiling it with unit squares of the appropriate unit fraction side lengths, and show that the area is the same as would be found by multiplying the side lengths. Multiply fractional side lengths to find areas of rectangles, and represent fraction products as rectangular areas.

question.content: The area of the entire figure below is $1$ square unit.      **How can we calculate the area of the striped rectangle?**

images.alt: A square that has been split into 27 parts, set in 3 rows of 9 parts each. In the top row, the leftmost part  is striped to show that it is shaded both blue and purple and the other 8 parts have been shaded blue. In the middle and bottom rows, the leftmost parts have been shaded purple and the other 16 parts are unshaded.

hints.content: We can calculate the area of the striped rectangle by multiplying its $\purpleD{\text{width}} \times \blueD{\text{height}}$.
[[☃ image 1]]  [[☃ explanation 1]]  The striped rectangle is $\purpleD{\dfrac19}$ of a unit wide and $\blueD{\dfrac1{3}}$ of a unit high.

images.alt: A square that has been split into 27 parts, set in 3 rows of 9 parts each. In the top row, the leftmost part  is striped to show that it is shaded both blue and purple and the other 8 parts have been shaded blue. In the middle and bottom rows, the leftmost parts have been shaded purple and the other 16 parts are unshaded. Along the top of the  square, the columns are labeled one-ninth A bracket across the first column is labeled one-ninth. Along the left side of the square the rows are labeled one-third. A bracket across the top row is labeled one-third.

hints.content: We can calculate the area of the striped rectangle with the expression $\purpleD{\dfrac19} \times \blueD{\dfrac13}$.

question.content: The area of the entire figure below is $1$ square unit.      **How can we calculate the area of the striped rectangle?**

images.alt: A square that has been split into 27 parts, set in 3 rows of 9 parts each. In the top row, the leftmost part  is striped to show that it is shaded both blue and purple and the other 8 parts have been shaded blue. In the middle and bottom rows, the leftmost parts have been shaded purple and the other 16 parts are unshaded. Along the top of the  square, the columns are labeled one-ninth  Along the left side of the square the rows are labeled one-third.

hints.content: We can calculate the area of the striped rectangle by multiplying its $\purpleE{\text{width}} \times \blueE{\text{height}}$.
[[☃ image 1]]  [[☃ explanation 1]]  The striped rectangle is $\purpleE{\dfrac19}$ of a unit wide and $\blueE{\dfrac1{3}}$ of a unit high.

images.alt: A square that has been split into 27 parts, set in 3 rows of 9 parts each. In the top row, the leftmost part  is striped to show that it is shaded both blue and purple and the other 8 parts have been shaded blue. In the middle and bottom rows, the leftmost parts have been shaded purple and the other 16 parts are unshaded. Along the top of the  square, the columns are labeled one-ninth A bracket across the first column is labeled one-ninth. Along the left side of the square the rows are labeled one-third. A bracket across the top row is labeled one-third.

hints.content: We can calculate the area of the striped rectangle with the expression $\purpleE{\dfrac19} \times \blueE{\dfrac13}$.

question.content: The area of the entire figure below is $1$ square unit.     **How can we describe the area of the striped rectangle?**

images.alt: A square that has been split into 30 parts, set in 3 rows of 10 parts each. In the top 2 rows, the leftmost 4 parts are striped to show that they are shaded both blue and purple and the other 12 parts have been shaded blue. In the bottom row, the leftmost parts have been shaded purple and the other 6 parts are unshaded. Along the top of the  square, the columns are labeled one-tenth  Along the left side of the square the rows are labeled one-third.

hints.content: We can calculate the area of the striped rectangle by multiplying its $\purpleE{\text{width}} \times \blueE{\text{height}}$.
[[☃ image 1]]  [[☃ explanation 1]]  The striped rectangle is $\purpleE{\dfrac4{10}}$ of a unit wide and $\blueE{\dfrac23}$ of a unit high.

images.alt: A rectangle that has been split into 30 parts, set in 3 rows of 10 parts each. The parts in the top 2 rows have been shaded blue. The parts in the left 4 columns have been shaded purple. The first 4 parts in the top 2 rows are striped to show they are shaded both blue and purple. Along the top of the rectangle, the columns are labeled one-tenth. A bracket across the first 4 columns is labeled four-tenths. Along the left side of the rectangle, the rows are labeled one-third. A bracket across the top 2 rows is labeled two-thirds.

hints.content: We can calculate the area of the striped rectangle with the expression $\purpleE{\dfrac4{10}} \times \blueE{\dfrac23}$.  The expression $\purpleE{\dfrac4{10}} \times \blueE{\dfrac23}$ is another way of saying $\purpleE{\dfrac4{10}}$ of $\blueE{\dfrac23}$.
The area of the striped rectangle is $\dfrac{4}{10}$ of $\dfrac{2}{3}$.

question.content: The area of each square below is $1$ square unit.    **How can we calculate the area of the striped region?**

images.alt: Two equal-sized squares side by side. Each square  has been split into 10 parts, set in 2 rows of 5 parts each. In the first square, the parts in the bottom row have been shaded purple and the parts in the top row are striped to show they are shaded both blue and purple. In the second square, the first two parts in the top row are striped to show they are shaded both blue and purple and the last three parts in the top row have been shaded blue. The first two parts in the bottom row have been shaded purple and the last three parts in the bottom row are unshaded. Along the top of each square, the columns are labeled one-fifth  Along the left side of the squares the rows are labeled one-half.

hints.content: If we push both squares together, the striped region will form a rectangle.   We can calculate the area of the striped rectangle by multiplying its $\purpleE{\text{width}} \times \blueE{\text{height}}$.
[[☃ image 1]]  [[☃ explanation 3]]  The striped rectangle is $\purpleE{\dfrac75}$ of a unit wide and $\blueE{\dfrac12}$ of a unit high.

images.alt: Two equal-sized squares side by side. Each square  has been split into 10 parts, set in 2 rows of 5 parts each. In the first square, the parts in the bottom row have been shaded purple and the parts in the top row are striped to show they are shaded both blue and purple. In the second square, the first two parts in the top row are striped to show they are shaded both blue and purple and the last three parts in the top row have been shaded blue. The first two parts in the bottom row have been shaded purple and the last three parts in the bottom row are unshaded. Along the top of both squares, the columns are labeled one-fifth. A bracket across the first 7 columns is labeled seven-fifths. Along the left side of the squares the rows are labeled one-half. A bracket across the top row is labeled one-half.

hints.content: We can calculate the area of the striped region with the expression $\purpleE{\dfrac75} \times \blueE{\dfrac12}$.

question.content: The area of each square below is $1$ square unit.    **How can we describe the area of the striped region?**

images.alt: Two equal-sized squares side by side. Each square  has been split into 12 parts, set in 3 rows of 4 parts each. In the first square, the parts in the bottom row have been shaded purple and the parts in the middle and top rows are striped to show they are shaded both blue and purple. In the second square, the leftmost parts in the top and middle rows are striped to show they are shaded both blue and purple and the last three parts in each of these rows have been shaded blue. The leftmost part in the bottom row have been shaded purple and the last three parts in the bottom row are unshaded. Along the top of each square, the columns are labeled one-fourth.  Along the left side of the squares the rows are labeled one-third.

hints.content: If we push both squares together, the striped region will form a rectangle.  We can calculate the area of the striped rectangle by multiplying its $\purpleE{\text{width}} \times \blueE{\text{height}}$.
[[☃ image 1]]  [[☃ explanation 3]]  The striped rectangle is $\purpleE{\dfrac54}$ of a unit wide and $\blueE{\dfrac23}$ of a unit high.

images.alt: Two equal-sized squares side by side. Each square  has been split into 12 parts, set in 3 rows of 4 parts each. In the first square, the parts in the bottom row have been shaded purple and the parts in the top 2 rows are striped to show they are shaded both blue and purple. In the second square, the leftmost parts in the top 2 rows are striped to show they are shaded both blue and purple and the last three parts in the top 2 rows have been shaded blue. The leftmost part in the bottom row have been shaded purple and the last three parts in the bottom row are unshaded.  Along the top of the squares, the columns are labeled one-fourth. A bracket across the first 5 columns is labeled five-fourths. Along the left side of the first square, the rows are labeled one-third. A bracket across the top 2 rows is labeled two-thirds.

hints.content: We can calculate the area of the striped region with the expression $\purpleE{\dfrac54} \times \blueE{\dfrac23}$.  The expression $\purpleE{\dfrac54} \times \blueE{\dfrac23}$ is another way of saying $\purpleE{\dfrac54}$ of $\blueE{\dfrac23}$.
The area of the striped rectangle is $\dfrac{5}{4}$ of $\dfrac{2}{3}$.

question.content: The tape diagram below represents fraction multiplication.      **Which expression represents the image?**

images.alt: A tape diagram labeled 1 with 6 of 7 equal parts shaded, each labeled 1 seventh. A brace labeled question mark spans 3 of the parts.

hints.content: The image shows that we are finding a fraction of another fraction.  We can use multiplication to show that we are making equal-sized groups, even when the size is a fraction!
The *whole* has $7$ equal pieces, with $6$ pieces shaded.  [[☃ image 1]]   The shaded parts represent $\dfrac{6}{7}$ of $1$ whole.

images.alt: A tape diagram labeled 1 with 6 of 7 equal parts shaded, each labeled 1 seventh. A brace labeled question mark spans 3 of the parts. A brace under the 6 shaded parts is labeled 6 sevenths.

hints.content: The *shaded parts* have $6$ equal pieces, with $3$ pieces marked.  [[☃ image 1]]  The selected parts represent $\dfrac{3}{6}$ of $\dfrac{6}{7}$.

images.alt: A tape diagram with 6 of 7 equal parts shaded, each labeled 1 seventh. The first 3 parts are shaded darker to represent another fraction. A brace labeled 3 sixths of 6 sevenths mark spans 3 of the first three parts.

hints.content: $\dfrac{3}{6} \times \dfrac{6}{7}$ is another way of saying $\dfrac{3}{6}$ of $\dfrac{6}{7}$.
We can represent the image with the expression $\dfrac{3}{6}\times\dfrac{6}{7}$.

question.content: The tape diagram below represents fraction multiplication.      **Which description represents the image?**

images.alt: A tape diagram with 10 equal parts each labeled 1 half. Braces labeled 1 span every group of 2 sections. 9 parts are shaded. A brace labeled question mark spans 6 of the parts.

hints.content: The image shows that we are finding a fraction of another fraction.  We can use multiplication to show that we are making equal-sized groups, even when the size is a fraction!
Each *whole* has $2$ equal pieces, and there are $9$ pieces shaded.   [[☃ image 1]]  The shaded parts represent $\dfrac{9}{2}$ of $1$ whole.

images.alt: The same tape diagram with a brace under the 9 shaded parts labeled 9 halves.

hints.content: The *shaded parts* have $9$ equal pieces, with $6$ pieces marked.   [[☃ image 1]]  The selected parts represent $\dfrac{6}{9}$ of $\dfrac{9}{2}$.

images.alt: The same tape diagram with the question mark replaced with 6 ninths of 9 halves.

hints.content: We can represent the image with the description $\dfrac{6}{9}$ of $\dfrac{9}{2}$.

question.content: The tape diagrams below represent fraction multiplication.      **Which description represents the image?**

images.alt: A tape diagram labeled 1 with 3 of 4 equal parts labeled 1 fourth shaded.
The same tape diagram as above, with each part split in 3 equal parts for a total of 12 equal parts. A brace labeled question mark spans 4 of the parts.

hints.content: The image shows that we are finding a fraction of another fraction.  We can use multiplication to show that we are making equal-sized groups, even when the size is a fraction!
The *whole* has $4$ equal pieces, with $3$ pieces shaded.   [[☃ image 1]]  The shaded parts represent $\dfrac{3}{4}$ of $1$ whole.

images.alt: A tape diagram labeled 1 with 3 of 4 equal parts shaded each labeled 1 fourth. A brace under the 3 shaded parts labeled 3 fourths.

hints.content: Then we split each *fourth* in $3$ equal pieces.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt:
A tape diagram divided into 12 equal parts. The first
four parts are shaded dark pink. The first 9 parts are labeled 1 ninth. A curved bracket across the dark pink parts is labeled with a question mark. The next five parts are shaded light pink. The last three parts are unshaded.

hints.content: Now, the *shaded parts* have $9$ equal pieces, with $4$ pieces marked.   [[☃ image 1]]  The selected parts represent $\dfrac{4}{9}$ of $\dfrac{3}{4}$.

images.alt: The same tape diagram with the question mark replaced with 4 ninths of 3 fourths.

hints.content: We can represent the image with the description $\dfrac{4}{9}$ of $\dfrac{3}{4}$.

question.content: The tape diagrams below represent fraction multiplication.      **Which expression represents the image?**

images.alt: Two rectangles, each split into 2 parts with a curved bracket above each rectangle labeled 1. Each part is labeled 1 half.  Three parts are shaded. One part is not shaded.

Two rectangles, each split into 2 parts. Each part is further split into 2 parts, so there are two wholes with 4 parts each. Five of the parts are shaded in a dark pink. One part is shaded in light pink. Two parts are not shaded. A curved bracket across the parts shaded in dark pink is labeled question mark.

hints.content: The image shows that we are finding a fraction of another fraction.  We can use multiplication to show that we are making equal-sized groups, even when the size is a fraction!
Each *whole* has $2$ equal pieces, and there are $3$ pieces shaded.    [[☃ image 1]]  The shaded parts represent $\dfrac{3}{2}$ of $1$ whole.

images.alt: Two rectangles, each split into 2 parts with a curved bracket above each rectangle labeled 1. Each part is labeled 1 half. Three parts are shaded. One part is not shaded. A curved bracket below the shaded parts is labeled three-halves.

hints.content: Then we split each *half* in $2$ equal pieces.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two rectangles, each split into 2 parts. Each part is further split into 2 parts, so there are two wholes with 4 parts each. Each part is labeled 1 sixth. Five of the parts are shaded in a dark pink. One part is shaded in light pink. Two parts are not shaded. A curved bracket across the parts shaded in dark pink is labeled question mark.

hints.content: Now, the *shaded parts* have $6$ equal pieces, with $5$ pieces marked.    [[☃ image 1]]  The selected parts represent $\dfrac{5}{6}$ of $\dfrac{3}{2}$.

images.alt: Two rectangles, each split into 2 parts. Each part is further split into 2 parts, so there are two wholes with 4 parts each. Each part is labeled 1 sixth. Five of the parts are shaded in a dark pink. One part is shaded in light pink. Two parts are not shaded. A curved bracket across the parts shaded in dark pink is labeled five-sixths of three-halves.

hints.content: $\dfrac{5}{6} \times \dfrac{3}{2}$ is another way of saying $\dfrac{5}{6}$ of $\dfrac{3}{2}$.
We can represent the image with the expression $\dfrac{5}{6} \times \dfrac{3}{2}$.

question.content: The number line below represents fraction multiplication.      **Which description represents the shaded length of the number line?**

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 2 with minor tick marks every one-tenth unit and major tick marks every one-half unit. The major tick marks are labeled from left to right: zero, one-half, one, three-halves, and 2. The number line is shaded from the 0 tick mark to the three-halves tick mark. Above the number line, a fraction bar is divided into 20 equal parts. The first 4 parts, parts 6 through 9, and parts 11 through 14 are shaded in dark green. The first 4 dark green parts are between 0 and the fourth tick mark after 0, the next 4 dark green parts are between one-half and the fourth tick mark after one-half, and the last 4 dark green parts are between 1 and the fourth tick mark after 1. The fifth, tenth, and fifteenth parts are shaded in light green. The first light green part is between the fourth  tick mark after 0 and the one-half tick mark, the next light green part is between the fourth tick mark after one-half and the 1 tick mark, and the last light green part is  between the fourth tick mark after  1 and the three-halves tick mark. The parts 16 through 20 are unshaded.

hints.content: The image shows that we are finding a fraction of another fraction.  We can use multiplication to show that we are making equal-sized groups, even when the size is a fraction!
The *fraction bar* has a shaded length of $3$ halves.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 2 with tick marks every one-half unit. Above the number line, a fraction bar is divided into 4 equal parts. The first three parts are shaded. The shaded parts are between 0 and three-halves on the number line.

hints.content: Each *half* has $5$ equal pieces, with $4$ pieces shaded on the number line.  [[☃ image 1]]  The shaded length on the number line represents $\dfrac{4}{5}$ of $3$ halves.

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 2 with minor tick marks every one-tenth unit and major tick marks every one-half unit. The major tick marks are labeled from left to right: zero, one-half, one, three-halves, and 2. The number line is shaded from the 0 tick mark to the three-halves tick mark. Above the number line, a fraction bar is divided into 20 equal parts. The first 4 parts, parts 6 through 9, and parts 11 through 14 are shaded in dark green. The first 4 dark green parts are between 0 and the fourth tick mark after 0, the next 4 dark green parts are between one-half and the fourth tick mark after one-half, and the last 4 dark green parts are between 1 and the fourth tick mark after 1. The fifth, tenth, and fifteenth parts are shaded in light green. The first light green part is between the fourth  tick mark after 0 and the one-half tick mark, the next light green part is between the fourth tick mark after one-half and the 1 tick mark, and the last light green part is  between the fourth tick mark after  1 and the three-halves tick mark.  There are 3 curved brackets above the fraction bar. Each curved bracket is labeled one-half. First curved bracket is above the first through fifth shaded parts, second curved bracket is above sixth through tenth shaded parts, and third curved bracket  is above eleventh through fifteenth shaded parts.

hints.content: We can represent the shaded length with the description $\dfrac{4}{5}$ of $\dfrac{3}{2}$.

question.content: The number line below represents fraction multiplication.      **Which expression represents the shaded length of the number line?**

images.alt: A fraction bar divided into 20 equal parts. The left 12 parts are shaded in a pattern: 3 dark parts, 1 light part, 3 dark parts, 1 light part, 3 dark parts, 1 light part. The right 8 sections of the fraction bar are not shaded. Below the fraction bar, there is a number line the same length as the fraction bar. A number line below the fraction bar is labeled 0 to 1 with minor tick marks every one-twentieth unit and major tick marks every one-fifth unit. Three lines move right across the number line. The first line moves right three tick marks from 0 to the tick mark before one-fifth. The second line moves right three tick marks from one-fifth to the tick mark before two-fifths. The third line moves right three tick marks from two-fifths to the tick mark before three-fifths.

hints.content: The image shows that we are finding a fraction of another fraction.  We can use multiplication to show that we are making equal-sized groups, even when the size is a fraction!
The *fraction bar* has a shaded length of $3$ fifths.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A fraction bar divided into five equal parts. Three of the parts are shaded. Below the fraction bar, there is a number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-fifth unit. The shaded area of the fraction bar runs between tick mark 0 and tick mark three-fifths on the number line.

hints.content: Each *fifth* has $4$ equal pieces, with $3$ pieces shaded on the number line.    [[☃ image 1]]  The shaded length on the number line represents $\dfrac{3}{4}$ of $3$ fifths.

images.alt: A fraction bar divided into 20 equal parts. The left 12 parts are shaded in a pattern: 3 dark parts, 1 light part, 3 dark parts, 1 light part, 3 dark parts, 1 light part. The right 8 sections of the fraction bar are not shaded. Above the fraction bar, across the first four shaded parts is a curved bracket labeled one-fifth. There is another curved bracket labeled one-fifth above the next 4 shaded parts. A third curved bracket labeled one-fifth is above the next 4 shaded parts. Below the fraction bar, there is a number line the same length as the fraction bar. The number line is labeled 0 to 1 with minor tick marks every one-twentieth unit and major tick marks every one-fifth unit. Three lines move right across the number line. The first line moves right three tick marks from 0 to the tick mark before one-fifth. The second line moves right three tick marks from one-fifth to the tick mark before two-fifths. The third line moves right three tick marks from two-fifths to the tick mark before three-fifths.

hints.content: We can represent the shaded length with the expression $\dfrac{3}{4} \times \dfrac{3}{5}$.

question.content: The number line below represents fraction multiplication.      **Which description represents the shaded length of the number line?**

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 1 with minor tick marks every one-twelfth unit and major tick marks every one-sixth unit. The major tick marks are labeled from left to right: zero, one-sixth, one-third, one-half, two-thirds, five-sixths, and one. The number line is shaded from the 0 tick mark to the first tick mark after one-third. Above the number line, a fraction bar is divided into 12 equal parts. The first 5 parts are shaded in dark blue. The dark blue parts are between 0 and the first tick mark after one-third on the number line. The next 5 parts are shaded in light blue. The light blue parts are between the first tick mark after one-third and five-sixths on the number line.

hints.content: The image shows that we are finding a fraction of another fraction.  We can use multiplication to show that we are making equal-sized groups, even when the size is a fraction!
The *fraction bar* has a shaded length of $5$ sixths.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 1 with tick marks every one-sixth unit. Above the number line, a fraction bar is divided into 6 equal parts. The first five parts are shaded. The shaded parts are between 0 and five-sixths on the number line.

hints.content: Each *sixth* has $2$ equal pieces, for a total of $2\times 5 = 10$ shaded pieces. The number line shades the lengths of $5$ of those pieces.  [[☃ image 1]]  The shaded length on the number line represents $\dfrac{5}{10}$ of $5$ sixths.

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 1 with minor tick marks every one-twelfth unit and major tick marks every one-sixth unit. The number line is shaded from the 0 tick mark to the first tick mark after one-third. Above the number line, a fraction bar is divided into 12 equal parts. The first 5 parts are shaded in dark blue. The dark blue parts are between 0 and the first tick mark after one-third on the number line. The next 5 parts are shaded in light blue. The light blue parts are between the first tick mark after one-third and five-sixths on the number line. A curved bracket above the shaded parts of the fraction bar is labeled five-sixths.

hints.content: $\dfrac{5}{10}$ is equivalent to $\dfrac{1}{2}$.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 1 with minor tick marks every one-twelfth unit and major tick marks every one-sixth unit. The number line is shaded from the 0 tick mark to the five-sixths tick mark. Above the number line, a fraction bar is divided into 12 equal parts. The first 5 parts are shaded in dark blue. The dark blue parts are between 0 and the first tick mark after one-third on the number line. There is a brown line after the first 5 shaded parts. The next 5 parts are shaded in light blue. The light blue parts are between the first tick mark after one-third and five-sixths on the number line. A curved bracket across the parts shaded in dark blue is labeled one-half times five-sixths.

hints.content: We can represent the shaded length with the description $\dfrac{1}{2}$ of $\dfrac{5}{6}$.

question.content: The number line below represents fraction multiplication.      **Which expression represents the shaded length of the number line?**

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to three-halves with minor tick marks every one-twelfth unit and major tick marks every one-fourth unit. The major tick marks are labeled from left to right: zero, one-fourth, one-half, three-quarters, one, five-fourths, and three-halves. The number line is shaded from the 0 tick mark to the first tick mark after three-fourths. Above the number line, a fraction bar is divided into 18 equal parts. The first 10 parts are shaded in dark purple. The dark purple parts are between 0 and the first tick mark after three-quarters on the number line. The next 5 parts are shaded in light purple. The light purple parts are between the first tick mark after three-quarters and five-fourths on the number line.

hints.content: The image shows that we are finding a fraction of another fraction.  We can use multiplication to show that we are making equal-sized groups, even when the size is a fraction!
The *fraction bar* has a shaded length of $5$ fourths.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to three-halves with tick marks every one-fourth unit. Above the number line, a fraction bar is divided into 6 equal parts. The first five parts are shaded. The shaded parts are between 0 and five-fourths on the number line.

hints.content: Each *fourth* has $3$ equal pieces, for a total of $3\times 5 = 15$ shaded pieces. The number line shades the lengths of $10$ of those pieces.    [[☃ image 1]]  The shaded length on the number line represents $\dfrac{10}{15}$ of $5$ fourths.

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to three-halves with minor tick marks every one-twelfth unit and major tick marks every one-fourth unit. The number line is shaded from the 0 tick mark to the first tick mark after three-fourths. Above the number line, a fraction bar is divided into 18 equal parts. The first 10 parts are shaded in dark purple. The dark purple parts are between 0 and the first tick mark after three-quarters on the number line. The next 5 parts are shaded in light purple. The light purple parts are between the first tick mark after three-quarters and five-fourths on the number line. A curved bracket above the shaded parts of the rectangle is labeled five-fourths.

hints.content: $\dfrac{10}{15}$ is equivalent to $\dfrac{2}{3}$.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to three-halves with minor tick marks every one-twelfth unit and major tick marks every one-fourth unit. The number line is shaded from the 0 tick mark to the first tick mark after three-fourths. Above the number line, a fraction bar is divided into 18 equal parts. The first 10 parts are shaded in dark purple. The dark purple parts are between 0 and the first tick mark after three-quarters on the number line. There is a red line after the first 5 shaded parts and a second red line after the next 5 shaded parts. The next 5 parts are shaded in light purple. The light purple parts are between the first tick mark after three-quarters and five-fourths on the number line. A curved bracket across the parts shaded in dark purple is labeled two-thirds times five-fourths.

hints.content: We can represent the shaded length with the expression $\dfrac{2}{3} \times \dfrac{5}{4}$.
